posts.name: Matthew Posthumus
posts.cooked:
Good Evening everyone - as the title implies I’m struggling with CAD - I am currently fairly proficient with 2D Drafting through AutoCAD but that has not at all translated to 3D software like OnShape in the slightest -  does anyone have some sort of jumping-off point that would help me stop crawling and start running?

thank you so so much for any available help

posts.name: Lucas Slurz
posts.cooked: onshape for frc is a super great resource

posts.name: Drew B.
posts.cooked:
If you’re looking to learn Onshape, the best spot to start is going to be the Onshape Learning Center at learn.onshape.com . Everything in the Learning Center is written and maintained by Onshape so it’s always up to date.

I’d recommend the CAD Basics learning pathway as a starting point and then finishing Onshape Fundamentals: CAD and Onshape Fundamentals: Data Management . At that point you’ll be in a good spot to explore the Learning Center for other content you want to learn more about.

Also, I’ll always plug for Orion DeYoe’s Onshape CAD Class which has a lot of awesome FRC-specific learning.

link_counts.title: FRC 3005 RoboChargers Onshape CAD Class | Onshape4FRC

posts.cooked:
Do you need to learn all of the main features of Onshape now, or can you prioritize things to learn?

Learning things can take time, but if making custom parts is more important, you can focus on that, or if assembling COTS parts is more important you can focus on that instead.

posts.name: Billfred Leverette (he/him/not Bill)
posts.cooked:
Matthew-7810:

i am the only person on my team who is trying to use CAD

Matthew-7810:

my current project us designing a custom chassis

If you’re the only one with working knowledge of CAD, does your team have the manufacturing resources to deliver on this custom chassis?  And if so, is it going to get you enough value for the invested time and money compared to an AM14U chassis to be worth the effort?

Maybe the answer is yes, but you wouldn’t be the first person putting in a ton of effort on one part of the robot only to realize too late that the effort came at the expense of something else on the robot.

posts.name: Matthew Posthumus
posts.cooked:
we are an extremely small team, meaning there are few personnel resources to go around -  I am attempting to create a chassis with materials entirely sourced from McMaster Carr because the shop we use prefers it that way

I have already created a design that implements the IM14U chassis, but believe that my time, before kickoff, will be best spent designing the McMasterCarr Chassis

posts.name: John
posts.cooked:
If McMaster-Carr integration with your CAD software is highly desirable, I do recommend Fusion 360. You can directly insert components from the McMaster Carr catalog into your 3D design.

I started putting together a Youtube tutorial series on Fusion 360 for FRC but it got pushed to the side (life gets in the way) but look around on YT (my user name)

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked:
Matthew-7810:

I have already created a design that implements the IM14U chassis, but believe that my time, before kickoff, will be best spent designing the McMasterCarr Chassis

I would strongly suggest using McMaster’s part downloads gor this, but also note that in many FRC use cases you’ ll be much better off using the FRC -specific vendors. I understand that the shop you’re at prefers MCM…that’s fine, when a part you want to use is sold by them.

In this case, it almost sounds like you’d be better served by doing a game piece manipulator using MCM parts, to go on top of the AM chassis. I would suggest 2018’s cubes as a fun test case.

posts.name: Matthew Posthumus
posts.cooked:
thanks for the help everyone! this is the chassis I was talking about - every item used is capable of being sourced from McMaster-Carr, and makeable within a fabricator shop

Sign in to Onshape, the #1 fastest growing CAD system in the world with over 4 million users.

I’m lucky enough to be in a team with enough resources and knowledge to make decent custom robot each year. I don’t know what it’s like to be in your spot. So take this with a grain of salt.

It looks like your team has used Everybot designs for the past 2 years (maybe more), and it seems you’ve done decently well with that. Does your team have an agreed-upon plan for 2024? Are you guys thinking Everybot? Modified Everybot? Completely custom design? And importantly, why? Why that choice?

Here’s why a lot of people recommend using the AM14U / kitbot chassis for newer / lower-resources teams:

If your drivetrain fails, you pretty much can’t do anything else. The mechanisms ontop of your drivetrain are basically useless.

The AM14U works. Maybe not as quick or as nimble as you’d like, but it works.

A lot of teams (not saying yours) might try and make a custom drivetrain, get it wrong, and be faced with point 1 (they can’t do anything in-game).

For similar reasons, people recommend using a design like the Everybot. But it’s natural (and good!) that teams want to move towards custom designs like you are now.

Here’s what I’d recommend:

Instead of making a completely custom McMaster design, why not make a modified kitbot drivetrain? I’m assuming that your shop preferring McMaster doesn’t prevent you from using kitbot. Maybe that’s incorrect. Maybe you want to upgrade the motors and gearbox? Again, this is still risky (and pricey probably) but you can always go back to the default motors and gearbox. Instead of having to design the whole drivetrain, now you only have to do a more-manageable part.

I’m assuming that your shop preferring McMaster doesn’t prevent you from using kitbot. Maybe that’s incorrect.

Maybe you want to upgrade the motors and gearbox? Again, this is still risky (and pricey probably) but you can always go back to the default motors and gearbox.

Instead of having to design the whole drivetrain, now you only have to do a more-manageable part.

Similarly for your scoring mechanisms, why not make a modified Everybot? One example from 2023 is 1591 . I found this really quickly so maybe there are better examples, but the idea is similar. Instead of having to design the whole scoring system, now you only have to deal with more manageable parts.

One example from 2023 is 1591 . I found this really quickly so maybe there are better examples, but the idea is similar.

Instead of having to design the whole scoring system, now you only have to deal with more manageable parts.

The idea behind this is minimize risks. Moving from an Everybot to a completely custom robot is a big jump with a lot of risks. Smaller steps let you guys move towards higher performance without letting you guys get stuck.

Looking at your current Onshape design, obviously it needs a lot of work. Not saying this to be mean, but we can agree that you’ ll need to put in some time before it starts. And with only 2 weeks until kickoff, that will be a stressful deadline to meet. With a kitbot chassis you’ ll have your drivetrain design done day 1 and you’ ll know it’ ll work. By designing a custom drivetrain now, you might not have it done day 1 and it may not work. By designing a custom drivetrain now, you’re taking a lot of risks.

I’ve CADed/designed about 1/5th of a custom robot each year and I’ve struggled each year with just one mechanism. CAD/design is really hard. If you’re the only one on your team, you’ ll be taking on even more work. As much as it might suck, leave the drivetrain for next year or summer and focus on scoring mechanisms for 2024. If you don’t want to sit around doing nothing before Kickoff, maybe try copying 1591’s robot in Onshape. (For those new to CAD/design, copying should be a challenge enough and gives you a lot of insight on “how to actually do this stuff”.)

If you really want to design a drivetrain, I’m sure CD can point you towards resources specific to that, but I still strongly urge you to consider devoting your limited time and resources to less-risky options.

Hopefully this reads the right way. Maybe I misunderstood your scenario but I’ ll be happy to correct myself if I did. Good luck with whatever you choose to do!

posts.name: Matthew Posthumus
posts.cooked:
I think I might have misspoken, we are using a mk4i swerve drive this year - we have resources this year we haven’t in previous ones, including new funds. - because of this we decided it might be a good time to try and branch into custom designs, especially in simpler parts - like the chassis.

our idea, so far, is to make a custom chassis that gives us massive control over our playstyle but use a modified every-bot scoring system - I recognize the difficulties herein, and if it comes to such a point that I cannot continue forward, I will scratch the project to discuss next steps with my team

I understand that there will probably be a performance hit, but the knowledge we get, we have decided, is more important

Ah, okay, gotcha. This makes your CAD make a lot more sense (I was wondering about the corners haha), and my old post irrelevant.

So then for a swerve chassis:

Where are you stuck? Is it knowing what sort of construction to use, or how to actually CAD it, or something else?

What are your manufacturing and purchasing abilities? There’s definitely a swerve “meta” of 2x1" Aluminum 6061 boxtube with a hole pattern. I could point you to Onshapes to copy from (e.g. 2023 1678 ) but I’m not sure if you would be able to construct that. You can defintely buy this extrusion/boxtube from FRC vendors, though, but again you said you had a McMaster preference.

Edit: I’m realizing as someone else is replying that someone’s going to bring up programming swerve. But I have no experience on that, so welp.

Edit: I also remembered this video exists. Maybe you don’t have to follow it exactly (e.g. not sure if you’d use the tube plugs) but it’s a good starting point.

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked:
CelestialMaelstrom:

You can defintely buy this extrusion/boxtube from FRC vendors, though, but again you said you had a McMaster preference.

McMaster also sells extrusion.  You’ ll probably end up needing to cut to length, unless you happen to land on a 2’ square robot (or the rules allow a 3’ square robot for the first time in forever), and you’ ll definitely need to drill mounting points, but it’ ll work.

(First one to bring up using T-slot extrusion for this: Only if you have the weight to spare, and only if you don’t mind realigning things every match or so. And yes, McMaster sells that too.)

McMaster-Carr is the complete source for your plant with over 595,000 products. 98% of products ordered ship from stock and deliver same or next day.

posts.name: Matthew Posthumus
posts.cooked: I had issue in the start, but thanks to yall i don’t anymore, learning onshape is not easy, and i don’t know everything i need to, but I’m in a good spot

If you are looking for some pre-designed mechanisms, while the everybot is an one option, it is not the only option. You could also check out the Rev starter bot. They build this out of 2x1 ion extrusion so it could be easier to adapt. Rev usually has Onshape files for stuff and you would be able to import from there and save yourself some work.

posts.name: Derek Finch
posts.cooked:
You may find that the chassis that 3737 use (entirely from McMaster Carr) will work for you. You only need a miter saw to cut it. However, it will not accept the SDS swerve. Instead consider the 3D printed (and competition tested) swerve drive designed to attach to this 3030 material.

20231219_232410 1920×1472 241 KB

20231219_232410 1920×1472 241 KB

See our full post here:

Release of compact, 3d printed swerve drive from frc team 3737 CAD

Cheers

To me, this sounds like your advice is to not use the SDS swerve (that they’ve already purchased), print your team’s swerve drive (which is once again very cool), and use it on their robot. Really not the best advice and sounds more like shameless promo than genuine help

@Loki I’m going to assume this reply was not meant for me and was intended for @Derek3737 because nowhere in any of my responses in this thread do I indicate anything about custom-fabbed swerve modules.
